The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA), the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York have agreed to merge. The announcement comes after months of tension between the institutions. MoMA and the Metropolitan initially announced in December 2019 that they would not merge, and in March of 2020, they merged with the South American museum of culture in Bogotá. The move marked the culmination of years of internal debate and conflict between the two institutions, which have been embroiled in a legal battle over royalties owed to a Polynesian artist who died in 1923 at the hands of the Japanese during World War II.According to the New York Times, the Met confirmed in a statement that the merger will not result in a fiscal impact on the museums, but will instead rely on the museum’s holdings and other assets for commercial purposes. The FOSMAC Foundation in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, announced today that a new artist-led initiative, called the FOSMAC Artist-Led Portal, will host the artist-led exhibition in its first iteration at the FOSMAC Kuala Lumpur Gallery on November 12–16. This exhibition will be organized according to the artist-led model pioneered by the FOSMAC in New Delhi, India, in the 1970s and is slated to run for a period of ten weeks.The initiative, which aims to provide a public space within FOSMAC to engage with contemporary art while providing an alternative to museums, is modeled after a similar collaboration between artist and FOSMAC curators Nirvana Abbashir and Prakash Saravanija in the city of Kota Bharu in India

The next Biennial should draw up to twelve thousand visitors from twenty-six countries and territories and will be held in late December to early January. In order to avoid overcrowding, the exhibition will run as a multi-day event. While the show will be centered around the theme of death and the body, “We will be able to celebrate our own mortality, our future selves, and the future of our planet,” the exhibition will also feature works by artists such as Mitch Albom, George Gervais, and Karl Pilkington.Tao Makarek, the president and CEO of the Exhibitionist and Artist Relief Fund (FAAR), said: “This is truly an unprecedented and unprecedented year for the arts.
